quote: Come on. Santa Anna didn't care    about the "rules of war." If    he'd executed Davy Crockett at    the Alamo he would've considered    it a point of pride.

All right. Try this: in    Eighteen thirty-six Crockett is    forty-nine -- quite old by the    standards of the time. His days    as an Indian fighter are well    behind him. He's just an ex-   Congressman... all reputation.    He's not going to be the man who    fights to his last breath. When    it's clearly hopeless, when the    ammunition is gone and Mexican    soldiers are swarming over the    Alamo's battlements, Davy    Crockett would surrender.    It's logical.
I'm not saying it couldn't have    happened, I'm just saying there's    no proof.

You are both wrong.         The only real question is whether    you believe in the legend of Davy    Crockett or not. If you do, then    there should be no doubt in your    mind that he died the death of a    hero. If you do not believe in    the legend, then he was just a    man... and it doesn't matter how    he died.
Well. I guess that settles that.
I guess so.
Shall we talk about something    else?
Sure.        The line in the dirt?

The line in the dirt. Now, I    suppose you're going to tell me    "Well, there's no evidence Travis    didn't draw the line." But, in    fact, there's a great deal of    evidence to suggest that the    story was invented by...
Enter.
Kor?
Nuq'nuh, Worf.     It's good to see you, my friend.
I welcome you to my home.
May I offer you refreshment?
I would be honored to share a    bottle of bloodwine with the Son    of Mogh.
I heard the news about Jadzia.
She died a warrior.
I expected nothing less.
To absent comrades.
Twenty-three oh nine. Very good.        The war goes well for you, Worf?    A long list of victories to your    credit, I trust?
I have been... fortunate.
The way of the warrior is not a    humble path. Show some pride in    your accomplishments! You've    earned it!
I will... try.        And does the war go well for you,    Kor?
No, Worf. It does not go well    for me. It seems my services are    not required in the present    conflict.
But... you are Kor -- a Dahar    Master, the man who held the    Korma Pass against T'nag --    your reputation alone should've    assured you a command.

I also have a reputation for... a    certain ruthless quality toward    those who would stand in my way.    Mind you, it is not entirely    undeserved -- in truth, I rather    enjoy being feared by my fellow    officers.        However, there is a price to be    paid for such... singledminded    devotion to one's ambition. I    made enemies... perhaps more than    were necessary.

I have no influence left in the    Empire. Even as our entire race    grapples with the Dominion...    there is no place for an old man    with too many enemies and not    enough friends.        That is why I have come here    tonight. It is not easy for me    to beg for help... but I have    nowhere else to turn.        Help me fight again, Worf. Help    me end my life as I lived it --    as a warrior!
Tomorrow I will go to General    Martok and find you a command. I    can give you an officer's    commission immediately. So as of    this moment, you are a soldier of    the Empire once again.
How many more reports does the    High Council require?
As many as last time.    (hands him another     PADD)    And Starfleet is still waiting    for your signature on these    repair requests.
There will come a day, Darok,    when your services as my aide may    no longer be required.
I look forward to that day with    great anticipation. Until    then...
Ah, Worf, good to see you.       Darok, thank you.
A pity Captain Sisko frowns on    summary executions. What can I    do for you?
Kor, the Dahar Master, came to    see me last night. He has been    unable to find a command and I --
Tell me you're not going to ask    me to give that man a ship!
I had hoped that--
Then your hopes are in vain!    That man is not welcome in my    house and I will certainly not    have him commanding a ship in my    fleet!
General... Kor is a friend and I    have already --
Not another word! Do you hear    me? Not a word! Now get out    before I forget that we are    brothers!

I plan to attack the Trelka Five    Starbase, then push deeper into    Cardassian territory.        I'll hit the Manora Shipyard, the    Jem'Hadar breeding facility on    Sheva Two, the supply depots in    the Borias Cluster...
It would take half the Ninth    Fleet just to destroy Trelka    Five.
I don't intend to destroy the    base, just damage it -- throw    them off balance and then move on    to the next target. Imagine the    chaos we'll cause once we're    behind their lines.

A cavalry raid...        Ancient Earth soldiers mounted on    horseback. They had the speed to    charge behind enemy lines to stir    up trouble and the mobility to    keep from being caught.        How many ships will you take?
Five birds of prey. The    battle cruisers are too slow and    unwieldy for this kind of    mission.
Do you want to take the Defiant?

Perhaps the Defiant should remain    here, protecting the station --    in case the Jem'Hadar try their    own "cavalry" raid. But it may    be prudent for the Defiant and a    dozen or so other starships to be    waiting for us when we return.
You mean you might be bringing    company back with you?
I'm sure you'll be ready to    welcome them?
With phasers charged.
The general is still with Captain    Sisko.        If you're going to anger him    again, can it wait until after    he's approved these personnel    transfers?
Worf! I'm glad you're here.    We're about to embark on an epic    journey into the very heart of    danger!
Come with me. I want to inspect    the Ch'Tang; she may be my next    flagship.
And what good is a flagship    without a crew to man her?
You'll be the death of me, Darok!    All right -- give me the    transfers!
Our disruptor targeting sensors    need to be replaced as well as    the guidance system relays.
Make a note of that for Chief    O'Brien. He should give the    Ch'Tang first priority.
Quick -- speak to me now before    Darok buries me in another    blizzard of paperwork.
I wish to speak with you about    Kor. I know that you have strong    feelings about this but--
CLEAR THE BRIDGE!
I did not expect to hear anything    further on this subject from you.
And I did not expect to be    forbidden to speak with you on    any subject. Have I become a    mere shuVak  to be    ordered about like Darok?
Of course not!    (beat, then     reluctant)
Very well. Talk and be done with   it.

He came to me, asking my help as    a friend. Kor is an old man. He    has no family, no influence left    in the Empire. He asked nothing    except for the chance to fight    and die as a Klingon warrior. I    told him I would speak with you    about finding him a command in    the fleet.
I would not give that man the    gnawed bones of my last meal,    much less command of a ship.
But why? There's no blood feud    between our Houses. And Kor told    me he's never even met you.

You can wound a man without ever    seeing his face.        When I was a boy, my family still    lived in the lowlands of Ketha    Province. We had very little,    but it didn't matter -- we were a    family of warriors. Fifteen    generations had served the Empire    as soldiers. My father had    higher hopes for me -- he wanted    his son to become an officer. It    took a great deal of effort, but    eventually he found someone    willing to sponsor me. I passed    the entrance exam on my first    attempt. All that remained was    final approval by the oversight    council -- a simple formality.        But my application was rejected    by one member of the council --    Kor.
Why?
Why?

Kor's family descends from the   Imperial Court itself. Kor is   "of the blood" -- born to rule by   the divine will of Kahless! And   what was I? A boy from the Ketha   lowlands. He couldn't bear the   thought of someone like me   joining the elite officer ranks.   So to my father's embarrassment   and my everlasting shame, my   application was denied. And with   the mark of Kor on my record I   couldn't even join as a common   soldier.        So I spent five years as a    civilian laborer aboard General    ShiVang's flagship.        As fortune would have it, the    Romulans made a foolhardy attempt    to board that ship, and I earned    a battlefield commission.    Unfortunately, my father did not    live to see that glorious day.    But if Kor'd had his way, I would    still be a civilian on that    ship... cleaning the officers'    mess.
I... understand.        However... I must tell you that    using my own authority, I    appointed Kor an officer in the    Ninth Fleet.
Made him an officer... just like    that. That's the difference    between his name and mine -- his    opens doors, mine closes them.
I did not anticipate that you --
It's done. Your "apology" is not    sought.        But know this, Worf -- he is your    responsibility. I want nothing    to do with him.
Do you remember breaking into the    Duke's harem on Renavi?
How could I forget? It's one of   Curzon's favorite memories...
Hi.
Hello.
Join us, my friend.
I'm on duty. I'll see you later.
Good to see you, Kor.
Still the same old Dax... and yet    not.
General Martok will not give you    a command.
Kesh! . Did you tell    him that I am still capable of --
It has nothing to do with your    capabilities. It is personal.        He says that you struck his name    from an officers list because his    family comes from the Ketha    lowlands.
Did I?        I don't recall... of course there    were so many officer lists... I    suppose it's possible...
It is an unworthy reason to bar a    man from serving the Empire.

Worf, you've been living among    this democratic rabble for too    long. I know your bloodline --    we both come from noble Houses.    Among our people that still    counts for something. If Martok    is a true Klingon, he should    appreciate that.
He does not.
Bah...        Did he... revoke my commission?
No. You will serve aboard the    Ch'Tang as Third Officer.
Third... ? Well, no matter. I've    overcome greater obstacles.        Thank you, Worf. You are a true    friend.
Report aboard at oh-seven    hundred. And... stay out of    Martok's way.
He will not even know I'm there.
Worf!        What was the... name of the    ship... ?
The Ch'Tang.
(quickly,     overlapping)    Ch'Tang! Of course. See you    there.
Transporter room reports that our    last crewmembers have beamed    aboard.
Very well.        Signal the squadron -- prepare to    get underway.       Stand by to cloak.
Aye, sir.
Helm, set course three two five,    mark zero zero three. Full    impulse until we clear the outer    marker, then go to...
The Dahar Master...
Third Officer Kor... reporting    for duty.
Take your station.
Return to your duties or I'll   find a crew that can! Helmsman!   I gave you an order!
Chah-Veh!
Kor... here... on our ship...
Don't you have something to do?
No.
Find something.
So what did Kor say when he met    you?

The usual. I have the same    conversation over and over again.    Everyone's shocked at first, then    they immediately start scanning    my face for signs of the person    they knew as Dax. "I don't    believe it. Is it really you?   Oh, I see a little Jadzia in your    eyes... a little Curzon in your    smile."
Isn't there always a period of    adjustment that joined Trills    have to go through... when people    are comparing them to previous    hosts? I'm sure it'll pass.
You're right. The last five Dax    hosts went through this.         That wasn't bad. You'd make a    pretty good counselor. Want to    trade jobs?
Oh, people would love bringing    their problems to me. "You    dreamed about what? You're    crazy. Now, get out of my    office! Next patient!"
Funny you should mention dreams.    Ever since my conversation with    Kor, I've been having the most    intense dreams about him.
Like what?

Being on a Klingon bridge    together... going off into    battle... drinking bloodwine --    which still makes me gag, by the    way... singing songs...         Part of me wishes that I was out    there with him now...

I hope he's all right. I mean, I    know I'm sort of contradicting    what I just said about trying to    set myself apart from my previous    hosts, but... the memories I have    of being with him are so vivid...    I can't bear the thought of    losing him. I'd give almost    anything for one more chance for    the two of us to be together    again... side by side... just    like it used to be.
Do you need something?
No. Nothing.
So what's your professional    opinion?
You're crazy.
Next patient!
What's the matter with you?    Someone forget to leave a tip?
It's Ezri. She... she... I can't    even say it.
Try.
She... wants to get back together    with Worf.
... and before the Cardassians    realized we were even there, we'd    destroyed the entire camp and the    relay station!
To General Martok -- victor of    Felton Prime!
Q'apla!
Let me have the honor to welcome    the Dahar Master to the humble    mess hall of the Ch'Tang.
Sit, sit. You do me too much    honor. On this voyage I am but    the third officer -- I expect no    special treatment.
Have you settled on an attack    plan for the starbase on Trelka    Five?
I'm going to send the Malpara and    Ning'tao in ahead of the rest of    the squadron.
They'll make a single strafing   run on the base and then head out   of the system. When the enemy   sends out repair crews to assess   the damage, then the rest of the   squadron will decloak.
With any luck, we'll catch them    with their entire damage control    effort underway.
Excellent! An excellent plan,    general.
I'm glad you approve.
Of course. It's the same tactic    Kang and I used against the    Federation during the battle of    Caleb Four.
You were at Caleb Four?
Of course he was!         Forgive the ignorance of these    children.
I was a young officer once; I    know how irrelevant the past can    seem.
We would be honored if you would    tell us about Caleb Four.
There's not much to tell    really... the battle was over    almost before the Federation knew   it had begun.

Now, you must remember that in    those days, the cloaking device    was a new piece of technology...    there were only a handful of    engineers in the Imperial Fleet    who knew how to operate them. So    before we left Chronos, I spent    three days in the engine room...
It is not the fault of the crew.    They are... not used to serving    with a legendary figure like Kor.
Bridge to General Martok.
Yes?
We are approaching Trelka Five.
Set defense condition one.
Understood.
Defense Condition One. All hands    to battle stations, repeat, all    hands to battle stations.
I'm... supposed to be...    somewhere...
Dahar Master... ?
Where are you going, lieutenant?
To... the bridge. We're    approaching Trelka Five.
The bridge!
Are you all right?
Of course! What are you waiting   for -- report to your station!
Chah Veh!
Concentrate...
Kai the first blood!
Planetary defense report.
Their shields are down to sixty-   five percent... three Cardassian    cruisers are in spacedock    orbiting the far side of the    planet... two of them are getting    underway.
The Malpara and the Ning'tao have   completed their attack...
The Malpara... is gone. No    survivors. Ning'tao is heading    out of the system... the    Cardassians are pursuing.
And leaving the base unprotected.         Helm, take us in.
Bring us to a hover three hundred    meters above the base.       Stand by to decloak on my    command.
Holding at three hundred meters!
Scan the base.
They've dispatched damage control    teams... two defense batteries    are down...       ... and they've just dropped their    primary shield grid.
Decloak the ship and open fire.
Shields down to eighty-five    percent!
Reroute emergency power to the    secondary shield emitters!
Fire torpedoes! Helm, lay in an    escape course!
Aye, sir!
Continue firing! Target their    primary reactors!
Chah Veh!
Bring us around for another pass!
Coming about!
No... no... only one... pass...
No... no... only one... pass...
Leave... system...
Do not worry my friend, all is    well.
Old... fool...
The Orantho reports their captain    and first officer are dead... and    they have a hull breach on their    port quarter!
Instruct them to continue firing!        Open a channel to Kang!
To... Kang?
Tell him we've succeeded, and    that the Federation outpost on    Caleb Four will be taken within    the hour!
Sir... Kang's been dead for years...
Prepare a boarding party. We're    going to take the base!
But sir... they have a garrison    of ten thousand...
By the... hand of Kahless... get    us out of here!

Victory is ours! The Federation    will rue the day they dared to    challenge the might of the    Klingon Empire! We will take    Caleb Four and raise our banner    above the smoking ruins of their    outpost!
Escape course! Now!
Engage... cloaks.
The Slivin and the Orantho have   cloaked... no pursuit from Trelka   Five.
No... time to waste... proceed...
... proceed to rendezvous... then   on to... the Manora shipyards.   Warp seven.
Medical team to the bridge!
Worf... get that man out of here.

I'm not a bad man, Jake. I don't    hurt people. I don't steal from    them. I don't even overcharge    them much. In a universe filled    with pain and suffering I offer    people an oasis.         I offer them love. But does    anyone offer love to me? No.
Come on. I've seen you with   women.
Too much rum, wrong garnish.
Of course I've been with women.    But none of them were Jadzia.    She was perfect. She played    tongo. She had a sense of humor.
She was tall.
And she was tall...
Well, you did have your chance.    Jadzia was here for three full    years before Worf showed up.

I was playing a deep game. I'm    not the kind of man who just    rushes in and declares himself.    I like the chase. But then    Mister Today-is-a-good-day-to-die    shows up and spoils everything.         And now, it's going to happen all    over again with Ezri. New body,    new personality, but she'll make    the same mistake.
Too much syrup. Can't you read?
It says two fingers.
That's not two fingers.
That's two fingers.
Oh, God...
Some bartender you'd make. Can't    mix drinks and can't dispense    advice.
You want my advice? Okay. You    think Ezri's making a mistake?    Tell her.
Sit her down, look her right in    the eye and tell her that you    think Worf is the wrong man for    her.
She won't listen.
Then she won't listen, but at    least you'll have tried. If you    don't say anything and they do    get involved...
I'll hate myself.
And enough people hate you    already. Why add to the list?
You know what? You're a really    bad bartender.         But... I think you're right.    Thanks, Jake.
No tip?
Enter.
Worf... I just wanted to say...    that I regret what happened on    the bridge yesterday...
What's done is done. Let us not    speak of it.

You're right. We should put it    behind us. It was a... momentary    lapse. It will not happen again.    Which brings us to the reason I'm    here.        I would like to... resume my    bridge duties.
I must think of the safety of the    ship.
You don't believe in me, do you?    You don't think I can serve as a    soldier of the Empire any longer?
If that's what you think, at    least have the courage to look me    in the eye and say it!
I do not believe you are up to    the challenge.
... and find out what's wrong with    the Ning'tao. I know Captain    Lurkan is young, but he needs to    realize the importance of...
... keeping formation.
I've been thinking about our next    objective. Perhaps we should go    after a bigger target...    something more threatening to our    forces.        What about the base on Caleb Four?
If you'll excuse me, I have    duties to attend to...
Your duties are right here.
Someone was just telling me about    the defenses on Caleb Four. Now,    who was it... ?
I believe it was our third    officer, general.
That's right!        Third officer! Tell us about    Caleb Four. Is it manned by    Jem'Hadar or Cardassian troops?
I thought it was a Federation    outpost.
But how can that be? The    Federation is our ally. Surely    Kor is aware of that.
Perhaps he's confused.
Confused? The Dahar Master?    Surely not! We must be the ones    who are confused!
Enlighten us -- who mans the base    on Caleb Four? Federation or    Dominion?
I think he's forgotten.
I think he's asleep.
Stop it, both of you! Don't you    have any respect for one of the    Empire's greatest heroes? He's    thinking it over. Give him    time... the last son of the House    of Kor should not be rushed.
How long should we wait?
Perhaps we should ask Kang.
Well, say something old man. Or    have you lost your tongue as well    as your mind?
Savor the fruit of life, my young    friends. It has a sweet taste    when it's fresh from the vine.    But don't live too long... the    taste turns bitter... after a    time.
The new personnel roster.
You've removed Kor from active    duty.
I saw no other choice.
Still. You're his friend. It    must've been difficult for you.
A friend would not have put him    in this position in the first    place.

I've hated his name for almost    thirty years. I've dreamt of the    moment when I'd finally see him    stripped of his rank and title...    when he would suddenly find    himself without the power of his    birthright and without a friend    in the world...         I had that moment. But I took no    joy from it.
Have you thought about what...    will become of him when we return    to Deep Space Nine?
I plan to speak with Chancellor    Gowron and try to... find Kor an    assignment on the homeworld.
I will... put in a word with    Gowron as well.
Bridge to General Martok.
Yes?
Pardon the interruption sir, but    sensors have detected a large    body of enemy ships.
On my way.
Where are they?
The warp signatures are bearing    directly astern.        They're Jem'Hadar fighters... and    they appear to be pursuing us.
How can that be?
Their lead ship is using some    kind of long-range tachyon    scanner to penetrate our cloaks.
Does the Dominion possess such a device?
They do now.
How many ships?
I've identified... ten vessels so    far... and sir, they're gaining on us.
How long until we're within their    weapons' range?
Two hours, twelve minutes.
Helm, have you located the    Defiant?
Yes, sir. They're waiting for us    in the Kalandra Sector, with    seven Federation starships. It    will take us...       ... three hours, forty-five    minutes to reach them.
If the Jem'Hadar could be forced    to drop out of warp for only ten    minutes... they would not have    time to catch up with us before    we rendezvous with the Defiant.
A fine theory, but how do we    execute it?
We could disrupt their warp    fields with an inverse graviton    burst. That would force them to    drop to impulse until the    gravitons dissipated.
We would need to generate a    massive burst to disrupt the warp    fields of a fleet that size.
A single bird of prey could do it    by diverting warp power to the    main deflector.
How long would that delay them?
They could reinitialize their    warp cores in less than two    minutes...
But if I engaged them in battle    while they were still at impulse,    they would be delayed longer.         I know I can do it.
What do you mean, you can do it?

The Orantho's Captain and First    Officer are dead. The Slivin's    deflector is damaged and can't    generate the graviton burst. And    the Ning'tao's Captain is too    young and inexperienced. I am    the logical choice.
But Worf, this means... that    you... you would be    sacrificing...    (can't say it, has     to say something     else)   ... the entire crew of the    Ning'tao.
I have thought of that. We can    beam most of the crew off before    I take command. I will need only    a half-dozen volunteers.
Send a signal to the Ning'tao...    tell them to prepare for a change    in command...
Yes?
I'm not hungry.
The food is for me -- I haven't    eaten in hours.
Men of our generation never stood    on ceremony. We ate when we were    hungry, we fought when we were    angered -- I miss the simplicity    of those days.
I miss a great deal about those    days.
The warriors on this ship... they    don't know what they missed. But    such is the way of children.    They often let the promise of the    future obscure the glories of the    past.
Is there a point to this    nostalgic indulgence?

Only that they are children.    Even Martok -- who, for all his    flaws, is a great warrior -- even    Martok is but a child compared to    you or me. They are quick to    judge and slow to forgive. They    still have much to learn.         We are being pursued by a    Jem'Hadar fleet. Worf believes    that he can stop them with a    single ship.
How?
It's a good plan. But it has one    flaw. It depends entirely on    Worf successfully engaging the    entire enemy fleet, if only for a    short time.
It can be done... the key is to    confuse their sensors in the    opening moments with a spread of    torpedoes...
Perhaps. But, it would take a    man with three times his    experience to accomplish such a    feat.
But such a man would have to be    certain of his abilities.
Such a man would only take the    job if he were certain.
It has been an honor serving with    you, Kor son of Rynar.
Worf!
Leaving for the Ning'tao, I take    it?
Yes.
I wanted to wish you well. I    look forward to seeing you at the    gates to Sto'Vo'Kor.
As do I.
Do you have any message you want    me to convey to Jadzia?

When I reach the halls of the    honored dead, I will find your    beloved and remind her that her    husband is a noble warrior... and    that he still loves no one but    her. Good-bye, my friend. Live    well.
Long live the Empire!
On the bridge?
If they succeed, you can drink to    their courage, and if they    fail... you can still drink to    their courage.
The Ning'tao is closing on the    enemy... she's initiated the    graviton burst...
Their warp fields are    destabilizing...         They're dropping to impulse!
By Kahless's hand... how many?
All of them!
The Ning'tao has dropped out of    warp. She's engaging the    enemy...
Die well, Worf.
Today... was not my day to die.
Worf!
But then who... ? Kor!
He surprised me outside the    transporter room with a    hypospray.
I hope that old fool understands    what he's doing.         How goes the battle?

We're approaching the limit of    our sensor range... but it    appears that the enemy formation    has collapsed... the Ning'tao is    maneuvering rapidly... she's    taking heavy fire from the    Jem'Hadar...         I've lost contact.
One ship against ten... it    doesn't seem possible.
He will succeed. He is Kor --    the Dahar Master.
Hi. I think I'm in the mood for --

Wait. I have something to say.    Now, you may think it's none of    my business, but someone has to    speak up and I've decided that    someone is me.         So. Here it is. I'll just say    it. Right now.
Okay.
You're making a mistake by    pursuing another relationship    with Worf.
Excuse me?
You heard me. I know how Jadzia    felt about Worf... but that was her    life not yours. You're Ezri Dax.    You need to give yourself a chance    to explore other relationships.
There's a whole universe out there   full of men and women -- why limit   yourself? You're young and   beautiful and full of life. Why go   after a man who's only a memory to   you?
I don't know.

Now, I've had my problems with    Worf, I'll admit it. But this    isn't about me or my feelings.    This is about you. And Worf has    done nothing -- and I mean    nothing -- to deserve you.    Shouldn't you try to find someone    who's willing to... win your    heart, not just inherit it? You    deserve better. In fact... you    deserve the best.         There. I've said my piece.
Can I say something now?         I'm not interested in another    relationship with Worf. I care    about him -- and I probably    always will -- but he's moved on    with his life... and so have I.
Oh. Well. Good.
And I'd also like to say that    what you just did was one of the    kindest, dearest -- and for you,    one of the most embarrassing --    things I've ever heard.         You're a real sweetheart.
Can I order now?       A Moscow mule.
Coming right up.
Did you hear that? She-- she   called me sweetheart.
Yeah. So?
She loves me.
What?
"Sweetheart."
You're certifiable, you do   realize that?
She loves me...
You're bruising the vodka.
He's done it!        The Jem'Hadar have run out of    time. They can no longer    overtake us before we reach the   Defiant.
How? How did that pompous old    man hold off an entire Jem'Hadar    fleet with one ship?
Does it matter?
Darok. Give me that bottle.
To Kor, Dahar Master... and noble    warrior to the end.
"My-cho kara, end-do keela... "
"Bay-do chum, ka ree-do meela.. "
"Stum-pa rip-to maaah-la ee-cho    ree-ka!/Ree-ka!/Ree-ka!/Maaaah,    so fah ka-lee te cho-pah, mee-to/    Ko-cha veh tah lee eh-mah sah-loh    moh... "
